titleStmt.title: Collection of Poetical Texts: the Śṛṅgāravairāgyamuktāvalī by Somanātha and the Rāmakṛṣṇakāvya by Sūrya Paṇḍita

repository.orgName: Bibliothèque nationale de France. Département des Manuscrits

msContents.summary: This manuscript in Devanāgarī characters, written in 1844 and bound in a Western style, contains two short poetical texts: the Śṛṅgāravairāgyamuktāvalī by Somanātha and the Rāmakṛṣṇakāvya by Sūrya Paṇḍita, along with an autocommentary. The Śṛṅgāravairāgyamuktāvalī also known as Śṛṅgāravairāgyataraṅgiṇī is an undated work by a certain Somanātha, identified as a Śvetāmbara Jain named Somaprabhācārya in the edition of the text, published in the fifth volume of the Kāvyamālā Anthologies. Each verse is followed by some lines of a short explanatory commentary. The Rāmakṛṣṇakāvya, better knonw as Rāmakṛṣṇavilomakāvya, is an extremely interesting poem composed around 1580 by the astrologer Sūrya Paṇḍita aka Sūryadāsa. It is probably the first example of bidirectional poetry in Sanskrit (See Minkowski 2004): the text reads as the story of Rāma, if read naturally from left to right, but it reads as the story of Kṛṣṇa, if its syllables are read from right to left. The genre of bidirectional poetry, probably created by Sūryadāsa himself, is a sub-genre of the much more extended phenomenon of simultaneous narration in Sanskrit literature or śleṣakāvya (see Brocquet 2010 and Bronner 2010). This manuscript has been probably created at the behest of Charles d'Ochoa (1816–1846), as its date, 1844, corresponds to the period in which the young scholar was in Maharashtra, looking for Sanskrit manuscripts.

extent.measure: 4 guard folios, 10 folios for the first text, 20 folios for the second text, 4 guard folios

supportDesc.foliation: Devanāgari numbers on versos, both on the upper-left margin and the lower-right margin.

layoutDesc.layout: The neatly organized written area is framed on the short sides by two ruled red lines. Daṇḍas are in red ink throughout the manuscripts. Running marginal titles are found on the upper-left margins: Śṛṃgā- Vai- or Śṛ- Vai- Mu- for the first text; Rāma- Kā for the second text. The written area has circa 24 akṣaras per line for the first work, and circa 28 akṣara per lines for the second work, which is in the Tripāṭha style. On the second guard folio, the writing: "Sanscrit D. 260". On the recto of the first numbered folio, in Devanāgarī script, accompanied by the red library stamp: || || atha śṛṅgāṛavairāgyamuktāvalīprārambhaḥ|| ||. On the verso of the folio numbered as 10, in Devanāgarī script: || iti śṛṃgāravairāgyamuktāvalī samāptaḥ ||. On the recto of the first folio of the second work, in Devanāgarī script: || || atha rāmakṛṣṇakāvyaprārambhaḥ || ||. One extra folio pasted at the end with a handwritten French note on the text.

origin.origDate: Date given in the colophon to the first work.
